description.plain:
“1950,” released on February 3, 2018, is King Princess’s debut song. On the day of the song, and visual, release, KP spoke to The Line Of Best Fit about the inspiration of the track:

Queer love was only able to exist privately for a long time, expressed in society through coded art forms. I wrote this song as a story of unrequited love in my own life, doing my best to acknowledge and pay homage to that part of history.

KP has also specifically cited the novel The Price of Salt by Patricia Highsmith as an inspiration behind the song.

I was reading a lot of gay literature and there was one book, The Price of Salt that really stuck with me because it’s just a beautiful story, and I think what I loved about it was it took place in the ‘50s and the way that queer people were allowed to be public was so censored it and it was all about body language and this kind of icy interaction because you had to hide yourself and so I was interested in the parallel between the metaphor of 1950 being how queer love looks in public and how it’s very similar to having a very cold relationship.

This song doesn’t just serve as King Princess’s debut. This is also the first song to be released by Mark Ronson’s record label, Zelig Records, an imprint of Columbia Records.

song.embed_content: Read “1950” by King Princess on Genius

body.plain:
“1950,” released on February 3, 2018, is King Princess’s debut song. On the day of the song, and visual, release, KP spoke to The Line Of Best Fit about the inspiration of the track:

Queer love was only able to exist privately for a long time, expressed in society through coded art forms. I wrote this song as a story of unrequited love in my own life, doing my best to acknowledge and pay homage to that part of history.

KP has also specifically cited the novel The Price of Salt by Patricia Highsmith as an inspiration behind the song.

I was reading a lot of gay literature and there was one book, The Price of Salt that really stuck with me because it’s just a beautiful story, and I think what I loved about it was it took place in the ‘50s and the way that queer people were allowed to be public was so censored it and it was all about body language and this kind of icy interaction because you had to hide yourself and so I was interested in the parallel between the metaphor of 1950 being how queer love looks in public and how it’s very similar to having a very cold relationship.

This song doesn’t just serve as King Princess’s debut. This is also the first song to be released by Mark Ronson’s record label, Zelig Records, an imprint of Columbia Records.

songs.full_title: King Princess - 1950 (Polskie Tłumaczenie) by Polskie tłumaczenia Genius
songs.title: King Princess - 1950 (Polskie Tłumaczenie)

annotations: Stone cold, will you miss me?

“Stone“ is a (historically) lesbian identity (and now expanded to other identities) that refers to a sexual partner who prefers to give sexual pleasure physically but not receive it. The classic book Stone Butch Blues by Leslie Feinberg explores this identity and is well known within the queer community. There are nuances to this dynamic but based on the exploration of 1950s butch/femme dynamics in this song it seems like this is a pretty overt callout to a stone butch.

I hope that you’re happy with me in your life
 I hope that you won’t slip away in the night
 I hope that you’re happy with me in your life
 I hope that you won’t slip away
 I hate it when dudes try to chase me
 I love it when you try to save me
 ‘Cause I’m just a lady

I wrote the verse one coming out of the shower and I wrote the chorus melody by myself. Then I went into the studio, I called my engineer Mike Malgerhoff, and I was like, “We got to get in this weekend.” Basically the next day, the next two days, I went to the studio and was like, “Nick you got to come in here help me finish this shit.”

Nick came in and it was me, Nick and Mike, and we’re sitting there and I played him the verse and the chorus. He’s like, “Dude Fuck yeah.” Then  we were like the melodies are done, let’s just get the second verse and let’s get the chorus lyrics in. It really started verse one, chorus, and then we wrote verse two and the bridge obviously. It changed very little from the demo also. The song was recorded almost two years ago, and it really has stayed almost the same. Which makes me super happy because it’s my production. I worked with my two very good friends on it.

“I hope that you’re happy with me in your life
I hope that you won’t slip away"—that’s sad. That’s a sad lyric. The song is about love and fear and the way you present yourself in relationships. There’s a lot of uncertainty in the lyrics. "Did you mean it when you said I was pretty?” And talking about someone not kissing you until you least expect it, it’s these moments of uncertainty that we all feel when we’re in love. I think that that lyric is just the summation of all of those feelings. “Are you gonna fucking leave me? Just want a heads up would be great ya know.”

I love that its so matter of fact. When I listen back to it the bridge, it’s always like “Awe.” It’s like a moment of sad reflection.

That you didn’t wanna live in a city
 Where the people are shitty?

When I was writing that, I was writing it from the perspective of somebody who moved from New York to LA. The whole EP is about this transition from New York to LA in a way. I think when I left New York I was really angry at New York just because I was. I felt like I was rejecting it in order to not miss it. I just love that, “I don’t wanna live in a city where the people are shitty.” I felt that way about New York for a moment and now I’m nostalgic for it. I’m happy I’m back obviously. But that was the perspective I was writing it from, of somebody who had moved across the country and rejected their hometown.
Did you mean it when you said I was pretty?

It goes back to “I’m just a lady.” I think a lot of people feel this way, but I feel this way about myself where I have these moments where I feel very feminine. I feel like a lady. Then I have these moments that are polar opposites, where I definitely feel more masculine and I wanted to play around with that. Its just a simple sentiment. When someone says something like, “You’re beautiful,” I find myself having those moments where like, “Oh my God they said that to me. She said I was pretty.”

It’s so simple, and I wrote this song with my really good friend Nick Long. I remember we wrote that line and we were like, “It’s so simple. Is it too simple?” I don’t think its too simple. I think there’s a lot to be explored in that it means something different for everybody. Everyone wants to feel pretty. I want to feel pretty. You want to feel pretty.

I will keep on waiting for your love
 For you, I’ll wait
 I will keep on waiting for your

It’s so funny it was just a moment in time but it feels like forever. It was just a moment in time but I feel like that’s when the best songs come out. You feel something so intensely for week and then you’re like “Wow that was wild. Remember when I was a crazy bitch like four days ago? What the fuck was going on? Why was I screaming?” I definitely wrote this song at a point of having a full moment. It wasn’t forever. I don’t think anythings forever.
So I’ll wait for you, I’ll pray

I love to play with religious imagery, because its traditionally being gay and being religious have been oil and water. It’s not at all true. I’m not personally religious, but I do find religious imagery really beautiful. If I could work, I’ve always had this idea that I could work it into maybe being a point of acceptance. If I could use that religious imagery to talk about gay love because, there’s nothing different between gay people and straight people. I think that the issue is when these outside elements like religion and where you’re from come in to play. It is a conscious choice to use religious imagery. But I think specifically in this song, doesn’t it sound good? I go from Gods to praying, I was like “YES! FUCK YEAH!”

So tell me why my Gods look like you
 And tell me why it’s wrong

Yeah, the whole songs about being in love with this idea of a person and being in love with a figure and turning the person that you love into more of a shrine than an actual relationship. I think in that specific line, “tell me why my Gods look like you,” it’s like if you hold the person that you’re fucking, loving, dating, whatever, on that highest shelf, your adoration for them becomes greater than the actual relationship. I think that’s what that line’s about, just about really looking up to the person that you want romantically.
I love it when we play 1950

I think it’s an analogy. It’s a metaphor in the sense that I think I was using the idea of the way that queer people had to hide their love in history, throughout our history. Being a parallel to unrequited love. Feeling like somebody’s being cold to you in a public space. Somebody’s giving you the cold shoulder to bring you in more, and how that looks very similar to the way people once couldn’t be gay in public. I wanted to pay tribute to that point in history, in an empowering way. Now when we can be gay in public for the most part in the cities that I’ve lived. I wanted to pay tribute to that.
‘Cause I’m just a lady

Isn’t that funny? Because I’m not a lady. It was supposed to be a joke, that line, because I fall somewhere in between everything, and I love that. To say, “I’m just a lady” once was an insult. It’s reclaiming it.

I hate it when dudes try to chase me
 But I love it when you try to save me

I moved to LA, and I immediately went to school. I was in this environment where I was around all these kids who were also doing music. I knew I was gay. I knew what I wanted, but you have to remind yourself. It’s like whenever you change your settings, your location. I feel like I in particular started to think more about my identity and how it sits in a room, and who’s observing it.

I just had this moment where I was like, “I fucking hate it when dudes try to fuck me, but I also absolutely adore when ladies try to chase me.” That sentiment is pretty sick. I love that. I feel like a lot of women feel that way about attention. It’s like I hate it when I don’t want it, but you love intentional people coming for you and trying to catch you.

description.plain:
‘Talia’ is the second single and track of King Princess'   debut project Make My Bed (EP).
This song was released on 13 April 2018.
Speaking about the track, King Princess said

“Everyone has different ways of dealing with heartbreak. This was mine, and I hope it helps somebody else in the same way”.

body.plain:
‘Talia’ is the second single and track of King Princess'   debut project Make My Bed (EP).
This song was released on 13 April 2018.
Speaking about the track, King Princess said

“Everyone has different ways of dealing with heartbreak. This was mine, and I hope it helps somebody else in the same way”.

annotations: I keep thinking that you’re standing on my floor

Strauss detailed that this line comes from a story her mother told her.   >My mom had a friend who passed away when she was young. She had a dream or a moment many years later where she saw her friend at the edge of her bed and had a conversation with her where her friend was like, “I’m okay.” So when I was writing “Talia,” I thought about this idea of “When I drink enough, I can see you at the foot of my bed. I can make you appear to me, I can taste your lipstick, and wake up next to you,“ or whatever the fucking lyric is.

I can see you dancing, I can lay down next to you
 At the foot of my bed
In an attempt to cope with the breakup, she’s living in memories of when they were together and happy, hoping to convince herself that she’s still living in that reality
I can taste your lipstick

For first-time listeners of King Princess' songs, the mention of lipstick may be a prominent indicator that Mikaela is queer, and writes to express that queerness in a passionate, unapologetic way.
In an interview with LGBTQ+ news website, them.us, KP tells her interviewer,

I talk about ladies and it’s just obvious, and I wanted it to be obvious. I think I wanted to emulate these male music figures that I had that were able to just talk about the women that they wanted to be with

King Princess' music is meant to normalize being LGBTQ+ by delivering her lyrics nonchalantly, as if she is just a man singing about a woman. Her songs serve as an undercurrent to the queer and lesbian movement, as she tries to change hetero-normative culture without conforming to it.
But four drinks I’m wasted
Mikaela is a bit of a lightweight, as four drinks is plenty to numb the pain of losing Talia.
That you’re waiting there for me

Mikaela still hasn’t recovered from the heartbreak of losing her lover, but she keeps hoping that she’ll come back. This breakup in particular is difficult to heal from, because Talia was important to her and they were most likely close. Losing a relationship that was a very steady part of Mikaela’s life was, and still is, a lot to bounce back from, and being alone is something she’s still getting used to.
You’ve walked out a hundred times
This line implies that Mikaela and Talia perhaps didn’t have the healthiest relationship. However, Mikaela is still surprised and heartbroken that Talia left.
Broke my heart now I’m wasting my time on you
Despite the relationship ending somewhat badly, Mikaela recognizes that she’s still “wasting her time” by thinking about Talia so often, and drinking to numb her feelings.

When you left, you took my bestest friends away
 And in this mess, I think I dug a thousand graves

The “graves” in this line are figurative. Since so many of KP’s friends were Talia’s friends, when the relationship ended KP had to bury all of those relationships. To her, it feels as if throughout this breakup she has lost so many people from her life that she has dug a thousand graves.
If I drink enough I swear that I will wake up next to you

King Princess hopes that if she drinks enough, she will hallucinate that she is still with her lover or pass out and dream of waking up with her.

This line conveys the desperation that King Princess is experiencing because she wants to be with her lover so badly; she is willing to hurt herself by abusing alcohol if it means she can just be with her lover one more time, even though it isn’t real.

Hey, my love
 Buried you a month or two ago

The use of my love suggests that King Princess still very much cares for the person despite their relationship dying and potentially ending badly.

The use of the word “bury” suggests two possible meanings to the song. Either Talia is dead, and therefore literally buried, or she’s simply out of Mikaela’s life. In this case, “buried” refers to Mikaela trying to forget everything they had together.

description.plain:
This songs thematically mirrors Madonna’s “Like A Prayer,” whose chorus reads, “When you call my name, it’s like a little prayer
I’m down on my knees, I wanna take you there…” Presenting a similar innuendo on the taboo of sex & religion.

song.title: Holy

album.full_title: Make My Bed - EP by King Princess
album.name: Make My Bed - EP

body.plain:
This songs thematically mirrors Madonna’s “Like A Prayer,” whose chorus reads, “When you call my name, it’s like a little prayer
I’m down on my knees, I wanna take you there…” Presenting a similar innuendo on the taboo of sex & religion.

annotations: I rule with the velvet tongue
Velvet tongue is a reference to oral sex, with which she controls her lover. Her position of ‘rule’ is an homage to the prior line where she refers to herself as a queen.
I’m dressed like a fucking queen and you’re begging, “please”
Again she creates a contrast between her and her lover as an authoritative figure. Here, she adopts the position of a queen while her partner is ‘begging,’ like a beggar, to be with her.
Honey, on your knees when you look at me

She is circling back to her holiness in this line. Telling her partner to bow down to her as one would kneel to a god or saint.

Straus spoke to Harper’s Bazaar about connecting her songs to religion:

Religious imagery has always been something that has been owned in the pop world. But I think if there’s a space for religion and sexuality to intersect, there can be some comedy about it because there is something extremely fucked up and fun about being the antithesis of a belief system. Gay people always have existed in the religious community, but never in a way that’s respectful.

Holy, holy, holy, yeah
 Holy, holy, holy, holy

These lines echo Allen Ginsberg’s 1955 poem “Footnote to Howl,” a poem that starts with the word holy repeated 15 times. Allen Ginsberg was a notable queer writer. “Howl,” widely regarded as a revolutionary event in American poetry, inspired the Beat literary movement.

As soon as you overcome an obstacle, a different one will come up. According to King Princess, “it’s about feeling like every time you get to the mountain, there’s another mountain, whether that’s your mental health or your love life or your work life.” – https://www.nme.com/features/music-interviews/meet-the-artists-king-princess-3406537

description.plain:
The first single from King Princess since her critically acclaimed Make my Bed EP, “Pussy is God” unabashedly celebrates gay love (the song was co-written with actress Amandla Stenberg, Straus' girlfriend) through the lens of religious imagery.

In an interview  with Radio NZ KP talked about the background of the song:

It’s simply not allowed to be played on many radio stations. Because you can’t say ‘pussy’… but our president can in a shitty way. So that’s really fun about the U.S.
You can’t say pussy but you can talk about abusing women and be a politician.
But my gay ass can’t say pussy on the radio. That’s crazy to me.
When I wrote it I wasn’t thinking about the political implications of it.
I think part of my experience is I feel like I’ve been gay for a really long time. So when I write I feel like I write music first… I think about it from a musical standpoint before I think about it from a sexual or political standpoint.
As our world is unfolding right now and we have a lot of shit going on I feel proud to be a part of a piece of art that is kind and loving towards women, while also appreciating the anatomy that has been marginalised through all of our history.

But my gay ass can’t say pussy on the radio. That’s crazy to me.

I think part of my experience is I feel like I’ve been gay for a really long time. So when I write I feel like I write music first… I think about it from a musical standpoint before I think about it from a sexual or political standpoint.

annotations:
(You really, you really)
 (You really, you really)

These samples come from “Oochie Wally” by Nas and Braveheart, released in 2001. This part comes from the chorus:

He really really made me scream and shout
He really taught me how to work my body
I’ve been praying for hours

This seems to be an innuendo or metaphor for going down on a woman. KP views the act as one of worship. More connections between religion and sex (between women) are found in other King Princess songs including ‘1950’ and ‘Holy’ with the line:

honey on your knees, when you look at me"

It creates the same links between prayer and sex with women.
Your pussy is God, and you know

Mikaela spoke to Harper’s Bazaar about connecting her songs to religion:

Especially with Madonna and Gaga and George Michael, religious imagery has always been something that has been owned in the pop world. But I think if there’s a space for religion and sexuality to intersect, there can be some comedy about it because there is something extremely fucked up and fun about being the antithesis of a belief system. Gay people always have existed in the religious community, but never in a way that’s respectful.

She also included religious allusions in “1950” and “Holy.”
I think star signs mean nothing

Straus is a Sagittarius, and her girlfriend at the time of this song’s release is a Scorpio; in astrology, this is seen as a bit of a challenging pairing due to the freedom-loving nature of the Sagittarius and the intensity and stubbornness of the Scorpio.

Straus is saying that their star sign compatibility is irrelevant as long as they truly like each other.
Your pussy is God and I love it

The connection between religion and female sexuality/queer love is one which frequently appears in Straus' work, most notably in “1950:”

tell me why my gods look like you

and in “Holy:”

Honey, on your knees when you look at me
I’m dressed like a fucking queen and you’re begging, “please”
I rule with the velvet tongue
And my dress undone
And I’ll get you lost but I’m having fun
Holy, holy, holy, yeah

She connotes her love of women with worship and conveys being with women as a religious experience.

Straus has spoken in interviews about how powerful she finds religious imagery and the beauty she finds in connecting it with queer love. This song is another appreciation of the two and further explores the powerful link between them.

The completely shameless and direct delivery of ‘Pussy is God’ makes this a pretty iconic song – there’s no beating about the bush when it comes to talking about her love of women and it’s extremely refreshing in a society where until recently the LGBTQ+ community was completely incapable of existing and loving visibly.

The song was first debuted live supporting Kacey Musgraves during the star-crossed: unveiled tour.  KP revealed on Twitter that the song was written for their two best friends from high school.  https://twitter.com/KingPrincess69/status/1503428627639189504?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

body.plain: “For My Friends” is the lead single off King Princess' upcoming sophomore album Hold On Baby.  The song was first debuted live supporting Kacey Musgraves during the star-crossed: unveiled tour.  KP revealed on Twitter that the song was written for their two best friends from high school.  https://twitter.com/KingPrincess69/status/1503428627639189504?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

annotations:
And I love you so much, going up the stairs
 At your new apartment

The changed line from the first pre-chorus where KP talks about their friend staining the carpet (presumably when they were in high school) to KP going to see their new apartment seems to signify the passage of time/growing up. Despite the years that have gone by and periods of not always being as close as they once were, the love KP has had for their best friends since they were teens has not wavered.

And I love you so much that I didn’t care
 When you stained the carpet

After releasing the song, King Princess revealed on Instagram that their friend reminded them that they did in fact care when she stained the carpet

      


 
 View this post on Instagram

 
   

  

   

   
A post shared by mr princess (@kingprincess69)

description.plain:
Like so many of her songs, King Princess first debuted this song on her Pussy Is God Tour . This song was first performed on August 1, 2019.

The song is most likely about King Princess' former significant other Amandla Stenberg whom she dated from 2017 to 2019.

She described this song as “cute and sad, perfect for any occasion. Wedding, funeral, corporate function, lesbian seance.”

song.title: Ain’t Together

body.plain:
Like so many of her songs, King Princess first debuted this song on her Pussy Is God Tour . This song was first performed on August 1, 2019.

The song is most likely about King Princess' former significant other Amandla Stenberg whom she dated from 2017 to 2019.

She described this song as “cute and sad, perfect for any occasion. Wedding, funeral, corporate function, lesbian seance.”

annotations: And I can’t watch this fall apart

During an October 2019 Verified interview with Genius, King Princess explained the meaning behind this line:

Musically I was modeling it after old-school bridges. Which is basically like a minor to major chord switch and having kind of background vocals and this weird drum, a bunch of drum fills. And it sounding almost orchestral, instead of it being like super wordy. I wanted it to just feel like notes moving down, like notes falling down and then that one line being: ‘I can’t watch this fall apart.’

Baby, you don’t gotta worry ’bout nothing (Ah)
 ’Cause everybody knows (Ah)
 That you and I got that somethin’ (Ah)

During an October 2019 Verified interview with Genius, King Princess explained the meaning behind these lines:

Everyone knew that there was some hot, heavy shit going down. Everyone knows, like, we hot together.
Cut off all these hoes (Ah)

During an October 2019 Verified interview with Genius, King Princess explained the meaning behind this line:

I cut off all my hoes for you, numbers deleted. No, not numbers deleted, but I think it was supposed to be a bit of a gag. I would never call someone a ‘hoe’ in a way that wasn’t endearing. But in this context it was supposed to be like, ‘I did this for you.’

We say “I love you,” but we ain’t together
 Do you think labels make it taste much better?
 Darlin’, do you think that if I talk enough
 I will make you wanna be mine?
 We ain’t together

During an October 2019 Verified interview with Genius, King Princess explained the meaning behind these lines:

I think that is the question of this song: is it better when you lock [the relationship] down? Is it more fun? Does it make the pussy taste better? I don’t know.

And bein’ chill, bein’ chill with you
 Oh, it kills, I ain’t chill at all, at all

During an October 2019 Verified interview with Genius, King Princess explained the meaning behind these lines:

I really don’t want to appear crazy in front of you. I can’t let you know this early on that I have zero chill. But if you are someone like me, I have a very hard time being chill. I’m not a chill girl. I’m like on eleven all the time.

And all this in between
 You think it’s hard for me to tell you’re fallin’
 Oh, we’re fallin’

During an October 2019 Verified interview with Genius, King Princess explained the meaning behind these lines:

It’s so visceral, I feel like when you are in love. You know that something kind of feels sickening and amazing at the same time. You feel like you are just exploding. The reason why we say we are falling in love is because it is a universal feeling. We all know what it is to feel completely out of control of a situation. And that lack of control can be the horniest thing in the world.

I know you’re with me
 And I’d love to see someone else call you

During an October 2019 Verified interview with Genius, King Princess explained the meaning behind these lines:

I know you are with me, and I would love to see some other bitch call you. It won’t work. It won’t happen.

body.plain: “Upper West Side” was released on June 15, 2018, as part of King Princess' Make My Bed EP. It finds King Princess reflecting on a girl she likes, but doesn’t want to like.

annotations:
I sleep great knowing we will never be the same
 ’Cause I’m downtown hanging out while you’re in a plane

this girl is off living a wealthy life, but it’s full of lies (see verse 1 lines 2 and 3) and of fake people.

mikaela, on the other hand is hanging out with true friends. people she can be honest with.

while she might not be as wealthy as this other girl, she seems a hell of a lot happier (or at the very least, she seems to think she is).
Train rides to the Upper West Side, yeah

In “14 Things About King Princess You Should Know!” by Billboard, she states that she is from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a stereotypically hipster neighbourhood. This is a stark contrast to the Upper West Side, a more “uppity” neighbourhood of New York City. The “train [ride] to the Upper West Side” highlights the differences between the two.
You’re no good ’til they’re looking at you

She’s implying that the song’s subject is attention-seeking, and further, isn’t fulfilled unless she is the center of attention. This line builds upon the overindulgent, self-centered, and spoiled characterization of this verse.
Credit cards cutting all of your lines, yeah
This refers to cocaine use. The fact that this girl uses cocaine, and specifically credit cards to shape the powder into lines, doubles down on her wealth.
Another bitch from the Upper West Side
The Upper West Side is one of New York City’s wealthiest neighbourhoods, next to Central Park and the Hudson River.

song.embed_content: Read “Cheap Queen” by King Princess on Genius
song.title: Cheap Queen

body.plain:
“Cheap Queen” was the first official look into King Princess’s debut album of the same name. Originally performed on the Pussy is God Tour,
Mikaela first teased the studio version in a tweet and announced the following day on Instagram and Twitter the release of the song.

annotations: A cheap queen

According to the artist, a “cheap queen” is “someone who is resourceful, who makes something out of nothing, who is a creator on a budget.” It’s a drag term used to reference artists whose creativity allows them to make something beautiful out of nothing. King Princess takes pride in being a versatile artist who can be anything they want
I’m a cheap queen

“Cheap Queen” is a reference to drag culture and how it has influenced Straus’s relationship with femininity.

In 2018, Straus told BAZAAR:

I’m a huge supporter and fan of drag. When I do makeup, it’s performative. I don’t really wear makeup, but I use it as a tool to talk about gender and sexuality.

Straus’s love for drag makeup is displayed on the cover of her debut album:
(Cheap queen)

As stated by King Princess, those lines are sampled from a 1938 PSA titled The Lesbian Menace that warns viewers about aggressive lesbians in the workplace.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w1s0AeSRnc8
They drive all the way to the west side to see my face (How do they do it?)

This contrasts with the song “Upper West Side”, in which King Princess describes a rich person from the ‘upper west side’ of New York as someone she would never be. In this song, KP is the one living on the west side, this time in LA.

I’m gettin’ too cocky since everyone wants me (Queen)
 It’s harder to be myself (Queen, queen)

King Princess has achieved major success in a short period of time. With this success comes a newfound fame that can completely transform the way someone experiences life. KP expresses a similar conflict about fame in her song “If You Think It’s Love” with the lyric,

My world keeps changing fast and normal things I never thought
I’d miss are obsolete
